elements.content: A novel dual-emissive metal–organic framework [Pb3(BPT)2(phen)2]·phen (1) has been obtained by hydrothermal reactions of biphenyl-3,4′,5-tricarboxylic acid (H3BPT), phen, and lead nitrate in aqueous solution. It consists of a main right-handed helix and three left-handed helical chains with the three left-handed helical chains sharing the same helical axis and further enwinding the main right-handed helical chain alternately. The BPT3– ligands join the 1D helical chains into 2D layers with the terminal phen liands extending upward and downward, which are further interdigitated into a 3D packing supramolecular architecture through π–π interactions between the phen molecules of neighbor layers. The second harmonic generation (SHG) measurement reveals that 1 is nonlinear optical active with SHG efficiency approximately equivalent to that of the standard potassium dihydrogen phosphate (KDP), and photoluminescent investigation displays that complex 1 exhibits distinct tunable yellow-to-violet photoluminescence by varying the excitation light.
elements.clean_text: A novel dual-emissive metal-organic framework [Pb3(BPT)2(phen)2]⋅phen (1) has been obtained by hydrothermal reactions of biphenyl-3,4',5-tricarboxylic acid (H3BPT), phen, and lead nitrate in aqueous solution. It consists of a main right-handed helix and three left-handed helical chains with the three left-handed helical chains sharing the same helical axis and further enwinding the main right-handed helical chain alternately. The BPT3- ligands join the 1D helical chains into 2D layers with the terminal phen liands extending upward and downward, which are further interdigitated into a 3D packing supramolecular architecture through π-π interactions between the phen molecules of neighbor layers. The second harmonic generation (SHG) measurement reveals that 1 is nonlinear optical active with SHG efficiency approximately equivalent to that of the standard potassium dihydrogen phosphate (KDP), and photoluminescent investigation displays that complex 1 exhibits distinct tunable yellow-to-violet photoluminescence by varying the excitation light.

elements.content: A novel dual-emissive coordination polymer [Pb3(BPT)2(phen)2]·phen (1) has been obtained under hydrothermal conditions. It crystallizes in non-centrosymmetric space group Pna21 and displays second harmonic generation efficiencies approximately equivalent to that of potassium dihydrogen phosphate. Luminescence investigation indicates that 1 displays distinct tunable yellow-to-violet photoluminescence.
elements.clean_text: A novel dual-emissive coordination polymer [Pb3(BPT)2(phen)2]⋅phen (1) has been obtained under hydrothermal conditions. It crystallizes in non-centrosymmetric space group Pna21 and displays second harmonic generation efficiencies approximately equivalent to that of potassium dihydrogen phosphate. Luminescence investigation indicates that 1 displays distinct tunable yellow-to-violet photoluminescence.

elements.content: Metal–organic luminescent materials have been extensively studied for their potential applications in lighting, fluorescent sensors, multimodal imaging and optical devices, as well as to be explored in cell imaging, and drug delivery monitoring and treatment. Recently, dual-emissive luminescent materials have come into prominence as biosensors and luminescent probes because of their distinct optical signals resulting from their interesting environment-responsive properties. For example, a dual-emissive-material enabling tumor hypoxia imaging has been designed by the Zhang group. A series of novel dual-emissive cyclometalated iridium­(III)–polypyridine complexes that serve as luminescent sensors for various biological receptors have been reported by Lo and co-workers, and other researchers. Meanwhile, nonlinear optics as the bridge linking photons and electrons has attracted considerable attention on signal transmission, processing and storage, and will give rise to great impact in information technologies, in which second-order nonlinear optical (NLO) materials play important roles. Traditionally, research of second-order NLO materials has been mainly focused on inorganic oxides, such as β-BaB2O4 (BBO) and LiB3O5 (LBO), which have been commercialized and applied worldwide. Recently, the synthesis of noncentrosymmetric MOFs with SHG properties have made great progress by taking advantage of metal centers and organic ligands. Lin played a pioneering role in the research of coordination second-order NLO materials and designed acentric polymeric coordination networks with dipolar NLO building blocks.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic luminescent materials have been extensively studied for their potential applications in lighting, fluorescent sensors, multimodal imaging and optical devices, as well as to be explored in cell imaging, and drug delivery monitoring and treatment. Recently, dual-emissive luminescent materials have come into prominence as biosensors and luminescent probes because of their distinct optical signals resulting from their interesting environment-responsive properties. For example, a dual-emissive-material enabling tumor hypoxia imaging has been designed by the Zhang group. A series of novel dual-emissive cyclometalated iridium(III)-polypyridine complexes that serve as luminescent sensors for various biological receptors have been reported by Lo and co-workers, and other researchers. Meanwhile, nonlinear optics as the bridge linking photons and electrons has attracted considerable attention on signal transmission, processing and storage, and will give rise to great impact in information technologies, in which second-order nonlinear optical (NLO) materials play important roles. Traditionally, research of second-order NLO materials has been mainly focused on inorganic oxides, such as β-BaB2O4 (BBO) and LiB3O5 (LBO), which have been commercialized and applied worldwide. Recently, the synthesis of noncentrosymmetric MOFs with SHG properties have made great progress by taking advantage of metal centers and organic ligands. Lin played a pioneering role in the research of coordination second-order NLO materials and designed acentric polymeric coordination networks with dipolar NLO building blocks.

elements.content: In an attempt to obtain a dual-emissive metal–organic framework displaying nonlinear optically activity, we employed biphenyl-3,4′,5-tricarboxylate (H3BPT) as the bridge ligand, which contains chemically inequivalent carboxylates with distinct coordination environments. A 3D polar nanotubular coordination polymer showing modest SHG efficiencies, approximately 2.5 times that of potassium dihydrogen phosphate, has been synthesized in our previous work by using this ligand. As a continuation of our research, we hereby report a non-centrosymmetric dual-emissive coordination ploymer with NLO activity and distinct tunable yellow-to-violet photoluminescent properties.
elements.clean_text: In an attempt to obtain a dual-emissive metal-organic framework displaying nonlinear optically activity, we employed biphenyl-3,4',5-tricarboxylate (H3BPT) as the bridge ligand, which contains chemically inequivalent carboxylates with distinct coordination environments. A 3D polar nanotubular coordination polymer showing modest SHG efficiencies, approximately 2.5 times that of potassium dihydrogen phosphate, has been synthesized in our previous work by using this ligand. As a continuation of our research, we hereby report a non-centrosymmetric dual-emissive coordination ploymer with NLO activity and distinct tunable yellow-to-violet photoluminescent properties.

elements.content: The chemicals were purchased from commercial suppliers and used without further purtification. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed on a Netzsch STA 449C thermal analyzer from room temperature to 800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min–1 with a 30 mL·min–1 purging gas flow of dry N2. Elemental analyses were determined on an Elemental vario EL III analyzer. The FT-IR spectra were measured as KBr pellets on a Nicolet Magna 750 FT-IR spectrometer in the range of 4000–500 cm–1. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were collected in the 2θ range of 5–40° with a scan step of 0.05° in a sheet glass on a Rigaku MiniFlex diffractometer. The fluorescence measurements were performed on an Edinbergh Analytical instrument FLS920. The UV absorption and Optical diffuse reflectance spectra were measured at room temperature with a PE Lambda 900 UV–visible spectrophotometer. The absorption spectrum was calculated from reflectance spectrum using the Kubelka–Munk function: α/S = (1 – R)2/(2R), where α is the absorption coefficient, S is the scattering coefficient which is practically wavelength independent when the particle size is larger than 5 μm, and R is the reflectance. The NLO property of 1 was tested on the microcrystalline samples with around size 100 μm by the Kurtz and Perry method using an Nd:YAG laser (1064 nm) with input pulse of 350 mV. KDP powder of similar particle size was also measured to serve as a reference.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

The chemicals were purchased from commercial suppliers and used without further purtification. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed on a Netzsch STA 449C thermal analyzer from room temperature to 800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min-1 with a 30 mL⋅min-1 purging gas flow of dry N2. Elemental analyses were determined on an Elemental vario EL III analyzer. The FT-IR spectra were measured as KBr pellets on a Nicolet Magna 750 FT-IR spectrometer in the range of 4000-500 cm-1. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were collected in the 2θ range of 5-40° with a scan step of 0.05° in a sheet glass on a Rigaku MiniFlex diffractometer. The fluorescence measurements were performed on an Edinbergh Analytical instrument FLS920. The UV absorption and Optical diffuse reflectance spectra were measured at room temperature with a PE Lambda 900 UV-visible spectrophotometer. The absorption spectrum was calculated from reflectance spectrum using the Kubelka-Munk function: α/S = (1 - R)2/(2R), where α is the absorption coefficient, S is the scattering coefficient which is practically wavelength independent when the particle size is larger than 5 μm, and R is the reflectance. The NLO property of 1 was tested on the microcrystalline samples with around size 100 μm by the Kurtz and Perry method using an Nd:YAG laser (1064 nm) with input pulse of 350 mV. KDP powder of similar particle size was also measured to serve as a reference.

elements.content: Preparation was under solvothermal conditions by the reaction of Pb­(NO3)2 (19.8 mg, 0.06 mmol), H3BPT (11.4 mg 0.04 mmol), phenanthroline (11.9 mg, 0.06 mmol), and NaOH (4.8 mg, 0.12 mmol) in a solution of distilled water (4.0 mL) at 160 °C for 3 days. Colorless block crystals of 1 were obtained after cooling the sample to room temperature. The crystalline samples were thoroughly washed several times with water and methanol, and dried under a vacuum overnight (yield: 52% based on Pb). Elemental analysis calcd (%) for 1: C 45.86, H 2.21, N 4.86; found: C 45.50, H 2.32; N 4.92. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3050­(m), 1602­(m), 1523­(vs), 1425­(m), 1386(s), 1145­(m), 1097­(m), 861­(m), 772­(m), 714­(m).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of 1 

Preparation was under solvothermal conditions by the reaction of Pb(NO3)2 (19.8 mg, 0.06 mmol), H3BPT (11.4 mg 0.04 mmol), phenanthroline (11.9 mg, 0.06 mmol), and NaOH (4.8 mg, 0.12 mmol) in a solution of distilled water (4.0 mL) at 160 °C for 3 days. Colorless block crystals of 1 were obtained after cooling the sample to room temperature. The crystalline samples were thoroughly washed several times with water and methanol, and dried under a vacuum overnight (yield: 52% based on Pb). Elemental analysis calcd (%) for 1: C 45.86, H 2.21, N 4.86; found: C 45.50, H 2.32; N 4.92. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3050(m), 1602(m), 1523(vs), 1425(m), 1386(s), 1145(m), 1097(m), 861(m), 772(m), 714(m).

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction was performed on a Rigaku Saturn724 CCD diffractometer using graphite-monochromatized Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. The Crystal Clear software was used for data reduction and empirical absorption correction. Structure was solved by direct methods using SHELXTL and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 using SHELX-97. All the non-hydrogen atoms were located from the Fourier maps and refined with anisotropic displacement parameters during the final cycles. The hydrogen atoms were positioned with idealized geometry and refined with fixed isotropic vibration parameters related to the non-H atom to which they are bonded. Crystal data as well as details of data collection and refinement for compounds are summarized in Table , and selected bond lengths are given in Table .
elements.clean_text:
Single Crystal Structure Determination

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction was performed on a Rigaku Saturn724 CCD diffractometer using graphite-monochromatized Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. The Crystal Clear software was used for data reduction and empirical absorption correction. Structure was solved by direct methods using SHELXTL and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 using SHELX-97. All the non-hydrogen atoms were located from the Fourier maps and refined with anisotropic displacement parameters during the final cycles. The hydrogen atoms were positioned with idealized geometry and refined with fixed isotropic vibration parameters related to the non-H atom to which they are bonded. Crystal data as well as details of data collection and refinement for compounds are summarized in Table , and selected bond lengths are given in Table .

Symmetry transformations used to generate equivalent atoms: A: x – 1, y, z; B: x, y, z – 1; C: x + 1, y, z; D: −x, −y, z + 1/2; E: −x – 1, −y, z + 1/2; F: −x – 1, −y, z – 1/2; G: x, y, z + 1; H: −x, −y, z – 1/2.

Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis indicates that 1 crystallizes in the non-centrosymmetric space group Pna21. A powder X-ray diffraction study indicates that the products are phase-pure (). The asymmetric unit contains three Pb­(II) centers, two bridging biphenyl-3, 4′, 5-tricarboxylate groups, two coordinated phen ligands and one guest phen molecule. As shown in Figure a, the Pb1 has a triangular prism coordination geometry and is coordinated by four oxygen atoms (O4, O5, O6, O8A) from three different BPT ligands (Pb–O distances range from 2.479(10) to 2.750 (11) Å) and two nitrogen atoms (N1, N2) from one phen ligand (Pb–N distances are 2.553 (12) and 2.691 (13) Å). The Pb2 is seven-coordinated and resides in a distorted pentagonal bipyramid environment with five oxygen atoms (O1E, O3C, O4C, O11, O12) provided by three different BPT ligands (Pb–O distances range from 2.563 (11) to 2.711 (11) Å) and two nitrogen atoms (N3, N4) provided by one phen ligand (Pb–N distances are 2.604 (11) and 2.737 (14) Å). However, Pb3 is coordinated by seven oxygen atoms from four different BPT ligands (Pb–O distances range from 2.528 (10) to 2.666 (18) Å) with no phen nitrogen atom coordinated (Figure b). The carboxyl groups of BPT3– show four kinds of coordination modes to coordinate to the Pb ions in 1: one is in bridging mode, another in chelating mode, the third one in chelating/bridging mode, and the fourth one in an unusual trimetallic bridging mode, as shown in .
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structure Description

Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis indicates that 1 crystallizes in the non-centrosymmetric space group Pna21. A powder X-ray diffraction study indicates that the products are phase-pure (). The asymmetric unit contains three Pb(II) centers, two bridging biphenyl-3, 4', 5-tricarboxylate groups, two coordinated phen ligands and one guest phen molecule. As shown in Figure a, the Pb1 has a triangular prism coordination geometry and is coordinated by four oxygen atoms (O4, O5, O6, O8A) from three different BPT ligands (Pb-O distances range from 2.479(10) to 2.750 (11) Å) and two nitrogen atoms (N1, N2) from one phen ligand (Pb-N distances are 2.553 (12) and 2.691 (13) Å). The Pb2 is seven-coordinated and resides in a distorted pentagonal bipyramid environment with five oxygen atoms (O1E, O3C, O4C, O11, O12) provided by three different BPT ligands (Pb-O distances range from 2.563 (11) to 2.711 (11) Å) and two nitrogen atoms (N3, N4) provided by one phen ligand (Pb-N distances are 2.604 (11) and 2.737 (14) Å). However, Pb3 is coordinated by seven oxygen atoms from four different BPT ligands (Pb-O distances range from 2.528 (10) to 2.666 (18) Å) with no phen nitrogen atom coordinated (Figure b). The carboxyl groups of BPT3- show four kinds of coordination modes to coordinate to the Pb ions in 1: one is in bridging mode, another in chelating mode, the third one in chelating/bridging mode, and the fourth one in an unusual trimetallic bridging mode, as shown in .

elements.content: (a) The coordination environments of the Pb1 ions in 1; (b) the coordination environments of the Pb2 and Pb3 ions. Symmetry code: A, −1 + x, y, z; B, x, y, −1 + z; C, 1 + x, y, z; D, −x, – y, 0.5 + z; E, −1 – x, −y, 0.5 + z (the H atoms and the C atoms of phen ligand are not shown for clarity).
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) The coordination environments of the Pb1 ions in 1; (b) the coordination environments of the Pb2 and Pb3 ions. Symmetry code: A, -1 + x, y, z; B, x, y, -1 + z; C, 1 + x, y, z; D, -x, - y, 0.5 + z; E, -1 - x, -y, 0.5 + z (the H atoms and the C atoms of phen ligand are not shown for clarity).

elements.content: Interestingly, the neighboring Pb1, Pb2 and Pb3 ions are first linked by carboxylic O atoms from BPT3– ligands to generate a one-dimensional metallic chain structure along the c axis (Figure a). The 1D metal–oxygen chain actually contains four helical chains, of which one main right-handed helix in a repeating unit of six Pb ions and six oxygen atoms with a pitch of 13.32 Å (Figure b), and three left-handed helical chains based on the repeating unit of four BPT groups. The three left-handed helical chains share the same helical axis and enwind the main helical chain alternately with a pitch of 39.96 Å (Figure c). The BPT3– ligands further join these 1D metallic chains into a 2D layer structure in the ac plane with phen liands extending outside the plane upward and downward (Figure d). The neighboring phen moleculars in different layers show π–π interaction to link the 2D layers to form a 3D interdigitated supramolecular architecture, as shown in Figure e. Here the isolated phen moleculars also display π–π stacking interactions with up and down layers () and hydrogen band interaction with the coordinated phen group (), which both strengthen the stability of the 3D supramolecular construction.
elements.clean_text: Interestingly, the neighboring Pb1, Pb2 and Pb3 ions are first linked by carboxylic O atoms from BPT3- ligands to generate a one-dimensional metallic chain structure along the c axis (Figure a). The 1D metal-oxygen chain actually contains four helical chains, of which one main right-handed helix in a repeating unit of six Pb ions and six oxygen atoms with a pitch of 13.32 Å (Figure b), and three left-handed helical chains based on the repeating unit of four BPT groups. The three left-handed helical chains share the same helical axis and enwind the main helical chain alternately with a pitch of 39.96 Å (Figure c). The BPT3- ligands further join these 1D metallic chains into a 2D layer structure in the ac plane with phen liands extending outside the plane upward and downward (Figure d). The neighboring phen moleculars in different layers show π-π interaction to link the 2D layers to form a 3D interdigitated supramolecular architecture, as shown in Figure e. Here the isolated phen moleculars also display π-π stacking interactions with up and down layers () and hydrogen band interaction with the coordinated phen group (), which both strengthen the stability of the 3D supramolecular construction.

elements.content: (a) The 1D metallic chain; (b) the main right-handed helix in a repeating unit of six Pb ions; (c) the three left-handed helical chains enwinding the main helical chain; (d) the 2D layer structure in the ac plane with phen liands as the hand extending the plane; (e) the 3D packing supramolecular struture.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) The 1D metallic chain; (b) the main right-handed helix in a repeating unit of six Pb ions; (c) the three left-handed helical chains enwinding the main helical chain; (d) the 2D layer structure in the ac plane with phen liands as the hand extending the plane; (e) the 3D packing supramolecular struture.

elements.content: In the FT-IR spectra of 1, the O–H stretching frequency of the broad band around 3268 cm–1 results from the H2O in air. The relatively weak absorption bands at 3050 cm–1 are due to the C–H vibrations of the aromatic ring hydrogen atoms and the characteristic bands of the organic ligand −COO at 1602 cm–1 for the asymmetric vibration and 1386 cm–1 for the symmetric vibration (Figure S3, ). The stretching bands of carboxyl groups shift to lower frequencies compared to that of the carboxyl group of free H3BPT ligand which has the characteristic peak at ca. 1700 cm–1, which is consistent with the X-ray structural analytical results. The thermogravimetric analysis of 1 was performed with a heating rate of 10 °C/min under N2 atmosphere from 30 to 800 °C. The results show that complex 1 remains stable up to 170 °C and a sharp weight loss of 30.6% appears in the temperature range of 170–300 °C, which is attributed to the loss of all the two coordinated phen molecules and one guest phen molecule (calcd 31.2%) (Figure S4, ). The next weight loss observed from 450 °C indicates the further decomposition of the compound.
elements.clean_text:
Infrared Spectra and Thermal Studies

In the FT-IR spectra of 1, the O-H stretching frequency of the broad band around 3268 cm-1 results from the H2O in air. The relatively weak absorption bands at 3050 cm-1 are due to the C-H vibrations of the aromatic ring hydrogen atoms and the characteristic bands of the organic ligand -COO at 1602 cm-1 for the asymmetric vibration and 1386 cm-1 for the symmetric vibration (Figure S3, ). The stretching bands of carboxyl groups shift to lower frequencies compared to that of the carboxyl group of free H3BPT ligand which has the characteristic peak at ca. 1700 cm-1, which is consistent with the X-ray structural analytical results. The thermogravimetric analysis of 1 was performed with a heating rate of 10 °C/min under N2 atmosphere from 30 to 800 °C. The results show that complex 1 remains stable up to 170 °C and a sharp weight loss of 30.6% appears in the temperature range of 170-300 °C, which is attributed to the loss of all the two coordinated phen molecules and one guest phen molecule (calcd 31.2%) (Figure S4, ). The next weight loss observed from 450 °C indicates the further decomposition of the compound.

elements.content: Second-order nonlinear optical effects were examined to confirm 1 in an acentric space (Pna21) as well as to evaluate its potential application as second-order NLO materials. The second-harmonic generation (SHG) measurements were carried out on the microcrystalline samples, using 1064 nm radiation, and the results reveal that 1 displays SHG efficiencies approximately equivalent to that of potassium dihydrogen phosphate (KDP). Here the modest powder SHG response of 1 may be attributed to the lack of a donor–acceptor system and only result from the effects of helical structure. The UV reflectance spectrum of complex 1 indicates that it is almost totally transparent in the visible region (). The optical diffuse reflectance study of 1 reveals an optical band gap of 3.4 eV (Figure ). On the other hand, complex 1 is air-stable and insoluble in H2O and common organic solvents, making it a potential candidate for second-order NLO materials.
elements.clean_text:
SHG Properties

Second-order nonlinear optical effects were examined to confirm 1 in an acentric space (Pna21) as well as to evaluate its potential application as second-order NLO materials. The second-harmonic generation (SHG) measurements were carried out on the microcrystalline samples, using 1064 nm radiation, and the results reveal that 1 displays SHG efficiencies approximately equivalent to that of potassium dihydrogen phosphate (KDP). Here the modest powder SHG response of 1 may be attributed to the lack of a donor-acceptor system and only result from the effects of helical structure. The UV reflectance spectrum of complex 1 indicates that it is almost totally transparent in the visible region (). The optical diffuse reflectance study of 1 reveals an optical band gap of 3.4 eV (Figure ). On the other hand, complex 1 is air-stable and insoluble in H2O and common organic solvents, making it a potential candidate for second-order NLO materials.

elements.content: Optical diffuse reflectance spectrum of 1. Inset: the SHG signal of 1.
elements.clean_text: 3  Optical diffuse reflectance spectrum of 1. Inset: the SHG signal of 1.

elements.content: The photoluminescent properties of the free H3BPT ligand, phen ligand () and complex 1 have been investigated in the solid state at room temperature. The pure H3BPT ligand with emission at 400 nm (λex = 340 nm) and emission bands for free phen ligand are at 435 and 410 nm (λex = 350 nm). The emission spectrum of 1 is composed of two emission bands centered at about 455 and 575 nm (Figure a). The emission band at about 455 nm should be interpreted as the intraligand charge transfer of BPT3– ligand because it has the same half width with the pure ligand, and the emission band at about 575 nm may be assigned to the charge transition of the ligand-to-metal Pb­(II) center or the strong π–π stacking interactions in the compound. Interestingly, the intensity of the emission bands can be tuned by varying the excitation wavelength. When excited by 345 nm light, the yellow lower-energy emission band is much higher than the violet higher-energy emission band. The increase of the wavelength of excitation light gradually enhances the relative intensity of the violet higher-energy emission peak, and the change of emission lights can be observed (Figure b). The tunability of the photoluminescence spectra of 1 can be presumably assigned to the difference of the adsorption bands of the BPT3– ligand.
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescence Properties

The photoluminescent properties of the free H3BPT ligand, phen ligand () and complex 1 have been investigated in the solid state at room temperature. The pure H3BPT ligand with emission at 400 nm (λex = 340 nm) and emission bands for free phen ligand are at 435 and 410 nm (λex = 350 nm). The emission spectrum of 1 is composed of two emission bands centered at about 455 and 575 nm (Figure a). The emission band at about 455 nm should be interpreted as the intraligand charge transfer of BPT3- ligand because it has the same half width with the pure ligand, and the emission band at about 575 nm may be assigned to the charge transition of the ligand-to-metal Pb(II) center or the strong π-π stacking interactions in the compound. Interestingly, the intensity of the emission bands can be tuned by varying the excitation wavelength. When excited by 345 nm light, the yellow lower-energy emission band is much higher than the violet higher-energy emission band. The increase of the wavelength of excitation light gradually enhances the relative intensity of the violet higher-energy emission peak, and the change of emission lights can be observed (Figure b). The tunability of the photoluminescence spectra of 1 can be presumably assigned to the difference of the adsorption bands of the BPT3- ligand.

elements.content: (a) The solid-state emission spectra of 1 by varying the excitation under the same metrical condition; (b) PL images of sample of 1 excited at 345, 360, 370, 375, and 390 nm from right to left.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) The solid-state emission spectra of 1 by varying the excitation under the same metrical condition; (b) PL images of sample of 1 excited at 345, 360, 370, 375, and 390 nm from right to left.

elements.content: In summary, we have successfully synthesized a novel non-centrosymmetric lead coordination polymer (1) under hydrothermal conditions by using an unsymmetrical organic linker. Complex 1 consists of multihelical chains and shows packing interactions of phen molecules in adjacent layers to form a 3D interdigitated supramolecular architecture. Its SHG properties show that non-centrosymmetric coordination polymers have broad potential in the application for NLO materials. Luminescence investigation indicates that 1 is dual-emissive with distinct tunable yellow-to-violet photoluminescence by varying the excitation light, which provides a new route to study the fluorescent materials with tunable photoluminescence.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, we have successfully synthesized a novel non-centrosymmetric lead coordination polymer (1) under hydrothermal conditions by using an unsymmetrical organic linker. Complex 1 consists of multihelical chains and shows packing interactions of phen molecules in adjacent layers to form a 3D interdigitated supramolecular architecture. Its SHG properties show that non-centrosymmetric coordination polymers have broad potential in the application for NLO materials. Luminescence investigation indicates that 1 is dual-emissive with distinct tunable yellow-to-violet photoluminescence by varying the excitation light, which provides a new route to study the fluorescent materials with tunable photoluminescence.

cln_elements.content: Preparation was under solvothermal conditions by the reaction of Pb­(NO3)2 (19.8 mg, 0.06 mmol), H3BPT (11.4 mg 0.04 mmol), phenanthroline (11.9 mg, 0.06 mmol), and NaOH (4.8 mg, 0.12 mmol) in a solution of distilled water (4.0 mL) at 160 °C for 3 days. Colorless block crystals of 1 were obtained after cooling the sample to room temperature. The crystalline samples were thoroughly washed several times with water and methanol, and dried under a vacuum overnight (yield: 52% based on Pb). Elemental analysis calcd (%) for 1: C 45.86, H 2.21, N 4.86; found: C 45.50, H 2.32; N 4.92. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3050­(m), 1602­(m), 1523­(vs), 1425­(m), 1386(s), 1145­(m), 1097­(m), 861­(m), 772­(m), 714­(m).

Synthesis of 1 

Preparation was under solvothermal conditions by the reaction of Pb(NO3)2 (19.8 mg, 0.06 mmol), H3BPT (11.4 mg 0.04 mmol), phenanthroline (11.9 mg, 0.06 mmol), and NaOH (4.8 mg, 0.12 mmol) in a solution of distilled water (4.0 mL) at 160 °C for 3 days. Colorless block crystals of 1 were obtained after cooling the sample to room temperature. The crystalline samples were thoroughly washed several times with water and methanol, and dried under a vacuum overnight (yield: 52% based on Pb). Elemental analysis calcd (%) for 1: C 45.86, H 2.21, N 4.86; found: C 45.50, H 2.32; N 4.92. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3050(m), 1602(m), 1523(vs), 1425(m), 1386(s), 1145(m), 1097(m), 861(m), 772(m), 714(m).

cln_elements.content:
In the FT-IR spectra of 1, the O–H stretching frequency of the broad band around 3268 cm–1 results from the H2O in air. The relatively weak absorption bands at 3050 cm–1 are due to the C–H vibrations of the aromatic ring hydrogen atoms and the characteristic bands of the organic ligand −COO at 1602 cm–1 for the asymmetric vibration and 1386 cm–1 for the symmetric vibration (Figure S3, ). The stretching bands of carboxyl groups shift to lower frequencies compared to that of the carboxyl group of free H3BPT ligand which has the characteristic peak at ca. 1700 cm–1, which is consistent with the X-ray structural analytical results. The thermogravimetric analysis of 1 was performed with a heating rate of 10 °C/min under N2 atmosphere from 30 to 800 °C. The results show that complex 1 remains stable up to 170 °C and a sharp weight loss of 30.6% appears in the temperature range of 170–300 °C, which is attributed to the loss of all the two coordinated phen molecules and one guest phen molecule (calcd 31.2%) (Figure S4, ). The next weight loss observed from 450 °C indicates the further decomposition of the compound.

Fluorescence Properties

The photoluminescent properties of the free H3BPT ligand, phen ligand () and complex 1 have been investigated in the solid state at room temperature. The pure H3BPT ligand with emission at 400 nm (λex = 340 nm) and emission bands for free phen ligand are at 435 and 410 nm (λex = 350 nm). The emission spectrum of 1 is composed of two emission bands centered at about 455 and 575 nm (Figure a). The emission band at about 455 nm should be interpreted as the intraligand charge transfer of BPT3– ligand because it has the same half width with the pure ligand, and the emission band at about 575 nm may be assigned to the charge transition of the ligand-to-metal Pb­(II) center or the strong π–π stacking interactions in the compound. Interestingly, the intensity of the emission bands can be tuned by varying the excitation wavelength. When excited by 345 nm light, the yellow lower-energy emission band is much higher than the violet higher-energy emission band. The increase of the wavelength of excitation light gradually enhances the relative intensity of the violet higher-energy emission peak, and the change of emission lights can be observed (Figure b). The tunability of the photoluminescence spectra of 1 can be presumably assigned to the difference of the adsorption bands of the BPT3– ligand.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Infrared Spectra and Thermal Studies

In the FT-IR spectra of 1, the O-H stretching frequency of the broad band around 3268 cm-1 results from the H2O in air. The relatively weak absorption bands at 3050 cm-1 are due to the C-H vibrations of the aromatic ring hydrogen atoms and the characteristic bands of the organic ligand -COO at 1602 cm-1 for the asymmetric vibration and 1386 cm-1 for the symmetric vibration (Figure S3, ). The stretching bands of carboxyl groups shift to lower frequencies compared to that of the carboxyl group of free H3BPT ligand which has the characteristic peak at ca. 1700 cm-1, which is consistent with the X-ray structural analytical results. The thermogravimetric analysis of 1 was performed with a heating rate of 10 °C/min under N2 atmosphere from 30 to 800 °C. The results show that complex 1 remains stable up to 170 °C and a sharp weight loss of 30.6% appears in the temperature range of 170-300 °C, which is attributed to the loss of all the two coordinated phen molecules and one guest phen molecule (calcd 31.2%) (Figure S4, ). The next weight loss observed from 450 °C indicates the further decomposition of the compound.

Fluorescence Properties

The photoluminescent properties of the free H3BPT ligand, phen ligand () and complex 1 have been investigated in the solid state at room temperature. The pure H3BPT ligand with emission at 400 nm (λex = 340 nm) and emission bands for free phen ligand are at 435 and 410 nm (λex = 350 nm). The emission spectrum of 1 is composed of two emission bands centered at about 455 and 575 nm (Figure a). The emission band at about 455 nm should be interpreted as the intraligand charge transfer of BPT3- ligand because it has the same half width with the pure ligand, and the emission band at about 575 nm may be assigned to the charge transition of the ligand-to-metal Pb(II) center or the strong π-π stacking interactions in the compound. Interestingly, the intensity of the emission bands can be tuned by varying the excitation wavelength. When excited by 345 nm light, the yellow lower-energy emission band is much higher than the violet higher-energy emission band. The increase of the wavelength of excitation light gradually enhances the relative intensity of the violet higher-energy emission peak, and the change of emission lights can be observed (Figure b). The tunability of the photoluminescence spectra of 1 can be presumably assigned to the difference of the adsorption bands of the BPT3- ligand.

metadata.title:
A Non-Centrosymmetric
Dual-Emissive Metal–Organic Framework with Distinct Nonlinear
Optical and Tunable Photoluminescence Properties
